dialogue: Look at these two bars. They're divided differently, but do they show the same amount?
prompt: Are two thirds and four sixths equivalent? How can you tell?

workspace.description: Strip divided into thirds with 2 sections shaded
Strip divided into sixths with 4 sections shaded

options.text: Yes, because both bars show the same amount shaded even though they are divided differently.
No, because thirds and sixths are different sizes.
No, because one has 2 parts shaded and the other has 4 parts.

correct_answer.context: Both bars show the same total amount shaded (2/3 = 4/6), demonstrating equivalence despite different partition sizes

success_path_dialogue: Right. Two thirds equals four sixths.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at how much of each bar is shaded, not just the number of parts.

Let's think about this more carefully. Even though the bars are divided into different-sized parts, what matters is the total amount shaded. Compare how much of the left bar is shaded to how much of the right bar is shaded. Do they cover the same amount of space?

Let me walk you through comparing these fractions. The left bar shows 2 out of 3 parts shaded - that's two thirds. The right bar shows 4 out of 6 parts shaded - that's four sixths. Now here's the key: even though the parts are different sizes, look at the total shaded area. The shaded portion on the left bar takes up the same amount of space as the shaded portion on the right bar. They both fill the same length of the bar. So yes, two thirds and four sixths are equivalent - they represent the same amount. That's what equivalent fractions mean.
